title: 3  Day Three Practical:
text:
3.1 Question 4:

x <- seq(-2, 2, length.out = 500)
y <- sin(x)

plot(
  x, y,
  type = "l",
  lwd = 2,
  main = expression(paste("Plot of ", f(x), " = sin(x) for ", x %in% "[ -2, 2 ]")),
  xlab = "x",
  ylab = expression(f(x)),
  xlim = c(-2, 2))

title: 3  Day Three Practical:
text:
3.2 Question 5:
Result:

t_dist_set = sort(rt(1000,1))
theoretical_pop = sort(rnorm(1000000))
quantiles = theoretical_pop[seq(1,1000000, length.out = 1000)] 

envelope_matrix = matrix(NA, nrow = 1000, ncol = 1000)
for(i in 1:1000) {
  envelope_matrix[i, ] = sort(rnorm(1000))
}

lower_bound = apply(envelope_matrix, 2, quantile, probs = 0.025)
upper_bound =  apply(envelope_matrix, 2, quantile, probs = 0.975)

plot(quantiles, t_dist_set, ylim = c(-5, 5), xlim = c(-3, 3), xlab = "norm quantiles")
abline(a = 0, b = 1, col = "blue")
lines(quantiles, lower_bound, col = "blue", lty = 2)
lines(quantiles, upper_bound, col = "blue", lty = 2)




Target to Check Against:





[1] 1000  999

title: 2  Day One Practical:
text:
2.3 Question 3:

cars <- cars
Y <- cars$dist
X <- cbind(1, cars$speed)

beta_hat <- solve(t(X)%*%X)%*%(t(X)%*%Y)
beta_hat

           [,1]
[1,] -17.579095
[2,]   3.932409

title: 2  Day One Practical:
text:
2.4 Question 4:

model <- lm(cars$dist ~ cars$speed)
beta_hat2 <- model$coefficients
beta_hat2

(Intercept)  cars$speed 
 -17.579095    3.932409

title: 4  Day Four Practical:
text:
4.3 Question 2:

flights |> 
  filter(month == 1) |>
    group_by(carrier) |>
      summarise(mean_distance = mean(distance, na.rm = TRUE),
                sd_distance = sd(distance, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
        arrange(mean_distance)

title: 4  Day Four Practical:
text:
4.4 Question 3:
Why One Carrier’s SD is NA:
Because carrier “OO” only operated a single flight in January. The standard deviation of a single value cannot be calculated.

flights |> 
  filter(carrier == "OO" & month == 1) |>
    select(month, carrier, distance)

# A tibble: 1 × 3
  month carrier distance
  <int> <chr>      <dbl>
1     1 OO           733


Why One Carrier’s SD is Zero:
Because all of the flights carrier “YV” operated in January were the same distance. The standard deviation of n values when all of the values are equal is always 0.

flights |> 
  filter(carrier == "YV" & month == 1) |>
    select(month, carrier, distance)

# A tibble: 46 × 3
   month carrier distance
   <int> <chr>      <dbl>
 1     1 YV           229
 2     1 YV           229
 3     1 YV           229
 4     1 YV           229
 5     1 YV           229
 6     1 YV           229
 7     1 YV           229
 8     1 YV           229
 9     1 YV           229
10     1 YV           229
# ℹ 36 more rows

4.6 Question 5:

prop_flights_delayed <- flights |>
  summarise("Proportion Flights Delayed" = mean(dep_delay > 0 & arr_delay <= 0, na.rm = TRUE))

prop_flights_delayed

  `Proportion Flights Delayed`
                         <dbl>
1                        0.108

title: 4  Day Four Practical:
text:
4.7 Question 6:
View Airlines as a Tibble:

# Airlines as a tibble
airlines <- as_tibble(nycflights13::airlines)

Identifying Routes that More Than One Airline Flies:

multi_carrier_routes <- flights |>
  filter(!is.na(arr_delay)) |>
    group_by(origin, dest) |>
      summarise(n_carriers = n_distinct(carrier)) |>
        filter(n_carriers > 1)

multi_carrier_routes

# A tibble: 127 × 3
# Groups:   origin [3]
   origin dest  n_carriers
   <chr>  <chr>      <int>
 1 EWR    ATL            4
 2 EWR    AUS            2
 3 EWR    BDL            2
 4 EWR    BNA            2
 5 EWR    BOS            3
 6 EWR    BWI            2
 7 EWR    CHS            2
 8 EWR    CLE            2
 9 EWR    CLT            3
10 EWR    CVG            2
# ℹ 117 more rows


Calculating the Average Arrival Delay for Each Airline for Each Such Route Excluding NAs and Finding the Names of These Airlines:

multi_carrier_routes_avg_arr_delay <- flights |> 
  semi_join(multi_carrier_routes, by = c("origin", "dest")) |>
    group_by(origin, dest, carrier) |>
      summarise(n_flights = sum(!is.na(arr_delay)),
                avg_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
        left_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |>
          rename(airline_name = name) |>
            relocate(airline_name, avg_arr_delay, .before = carrier)

multi_carrier_routes_avg_arr_delay

# A tibble: 341 × 6
# Groups:   origin, dest [127]
   origin dest  airline_name             avg_arr_delay carrier n_flights
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>                            <dbl> <chr>       <int>
 1 EWR    ATL   Endeavor Air Inc.                -6.25 9E              4
 2 EWR    ATL   Delta Air Lines Inc.             10.00 DL           3116
 3 EWR    ATL   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.         19.5  EV           1654
 4 EWR    ATL   United Air Lines Inc.            10.5  UA            102
 5 EWR    AUS   United Air Lines Inc.             4.28 UA            664
 6 EWR    AUS   Southwest Airlines Co.          -11.2  WN            293
 7 EWR    BDL   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.          6.78 EV            405
 8 EWR    BDL   United Air Lines Inc.            22.6  UA              7
 9 EWR    BNA   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.         17.7  EV           1677
10 EWR    BNA   Southwest Airlines Co.           -2.13 WN            564
# ℹ 331 more rows


Identifying the Airline with the Worst and Best Average Arrival Delay for Each Such Route:

best_worst_by_route <- multi_carrier_routes_avg_arr_delay |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
    summarise(
  
      worst_airline = airline_name[which.max(avg_arr_delay)],
      worst_avg_arr_delay = max(avg_arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
  
      best_airline = airline_name[which.min(avg_arr_delay)],
      best_avg_arr_delay = min(avg_arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
  
    )

best_worst_by_route

# A tibble: 127 × 6
# Groups:   origin [3]
   origin dest  worst_airline            worst_avg_arr_delay best_airline       
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>                                  <dbl> <chr>              
 1 EWR    ATL   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.               19.5  Endeavor Air Inc.  
 2 EWR    AUS   United Air Lines Inc.                   4.28 Southwest Airlines…
 3 EWR    BDL   United Air Lines Inc.                  22.6  ExpressJet Airline…
 4 EWR    BNA   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.               17.7  Southwest Airlines…
 5 EWR    BOS   JetBlue Airways                         6.87 ExpressJet Airline…
 6 EWR    BWI   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.               20.1  Southwest Airlines…
 7 EWR    CHS   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.               16.2  United Air Lines I…
 8 EWR    CLE   United Air Lines Inc.                   5.97 ExpressJet Airline…
 9 EWR    CLT   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.               20.5  US Airways Inc.    
10 EWR    CVG   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.               21.2  Endeavor Air Inc.  
# ℹ 117 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: best_avg_arr_delay <dbl>


Identifying the Route with the Greatest Difference Between the Best and Worst Performing Airlines:

greatest_gap_route <- best_worst_by_route |>
  arrange(desc(worst_avg_arr_delay - best_avg_arr_delay)) |>
    ungroup() |>
      slice(1)

greatest_gap_route

# A tibble: 1 × 6
  origin dest  worst_airline worst_avg_arr_delay best_airline best_avg_arr_delay
  <chr>  <chr> <chr>                       <dbl> <chr>                     <dbl>
1 JFK    ATL   ExpressJet A…                 128 Endeavor Ai…               1.40


Determining the Reason for this Difference:

# All Flights on Route:
JFK_to_ATL_diagnostic <- flights |>
  filter(!is.na(arr_delay) & origin == "JFK" & dest == "ATL")

JFK_to_ATL_diagnostic

# A tibble: 1,920 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      606            610        -4      837            845
 2  2013     1     1      807            810        -3     1043           1043
 3  2013     1     1     1325           1330        -5     1606           1605
 4  2013     1     1     1621           1548        33     1904           1830
 5  2013     1     1     1856           1855         1     2142           2142
 6  2013     1     2      606            610        -4      846            845
 7  2013     1     2      808            810        -2     1049           1045
 8  2013     1     2     1324           1330        -6     1552           1605
 9  2013     1     2     1551           1548         3     1838           1830
10  2013     1     2     1854           1855        -1     2126           2142
# ℹ 1,910 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

# All Flights by Airline With Worst Avg Arrival Delay:
JFK_to_ATL_diagnostic_EV <- flights |>
  filter(!is.na(arr_delay) & origin == "JFK" & dest == "ATL" & carrier == "EV")

JFK_to_ATL_diagnostic_EV

# A tibble: 1 × 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
1  2013    10     7      904            700       124     1133            925
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

# All Flights by Airline With Best Avg Arrival Delay:
JFK_to_ATL_diagnostic_9E <- flights |>
  filter(!is.na(arr_delay) & origin == "JFK" & dest == "ATL" & carrier == "9E")

JFK_to_ATL_diagnostic_9E

# A tibble: 52 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     4      615            615         0      851            855
 2  2013     1     7      614            615        -1      812            855
 3  2013     1     8      612            615        -3      901            855
 4  2013     1    10      613            615        -2      840            855
 5  2013     1    11      629            615        14      914            855
 6  2013     1    12      613            615        -2      839            855
 7  2013     1    13      612            615        -3      853            855
 8  2013     1    14      649            615        34      950            855
 9  2013     1    15      612            615        -3      927            855
10  2013     1    16      615            615         0      905            855
# ℹ 42 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>


The Reason Explained:
The reason for the size of this difference is because ExpressJet Airlines Inc. (carrier “EV”) only ever flew this route once and that flight happened to be severly delayed by 128 minutes. And because the airline only ever flew the route once its average arrival delay has not had the chance to ‘average out’ over multiple flights causing it be an outlier when compared to other routes whose average arrival delays conform far more to the law of averages.

Warning: Not all unique entries displayed for these non-numeric cols: id


Resolving Inconsistencies & Displaying Entries With Missing Values:

healthDataSetNoTypos <- healthDataSet |>
  mutate(gender = if_else(gender == "femal", "female", gender),
         disease_status = if_else(disease_status == "Healthy", "healthy", disease_status))

healthDataSetNoTypos

text: This assignment consists of the required STATISTICAL COMPUTING practicals.

title: 4  Day Four Practical:
